facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 15, 1958 of Orissa High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 194 of 1957.

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and order dated October 26, 1957 of Election Tribunal, Puri in Election Case No. 1/67 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated October 26, 1957, of the Election Tribunal, Puri, in Election Case No. 1/67 of 1957.

facts.text: Appellant and respondent No. 1 were candidates for election to Orissa Legislative Assembly from Daspalla double-member constituency, general seat.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the respondent No. 1 were, amongst others, candidates for election to the Orissa Legislative Assembly from the Daspalla doublemember companystituency

facts.text: Election held on February 27, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The election was held on February 27, 1957,

facts.text: Appellant declared elected on March 5, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellant was declared elected on March 5, 1957.

facts.text: Appellant obtained 17,700 votes, respondent No. 1 15,568 votes, respondent No. 3 3,589 votes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant obtained 17,700 votes, respondent No. 1 15,568 votes and respondent No. 3 3,589 votes.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 filed election petition questioning appellant's election on various grounds.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 filed an election petition questioning, on various grounds, the election -of the aPpellant.

facts.text: Election Tribunal dismissed the petition holding no grounds established.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal dismissed the petition holding that numbergrounds had been established to invalidate the election.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 appealed to Orissa High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 appealed to the High Court of Orissa against the order of the Election Tribunal.

facts.text: One ground: nomination of respondent No. 3 improperly accepted as disqualified being Sarbarakar of 10 villages in Nayagarh district.

anchor.surface_text: With reference to the third ground the High Court was of the opinion that a Sarpanch of the Grama Panchayat, though not a Government servant appointed by the Government, was nevertheless a person in the service of the Government as he performed many of the governmental duties and was also removable by the Government and such a person came within the provisions of s. 123(7)(f) of the Act.

arguments.claim: Sarpanch not in service of Government: elected by Panchayat (not appointed by govt), acts under Panchayat authority (s.8), no remuneration from govt, removal restricted (s.16).

anchor.surface_text: It was urged on behalf of the appellant that under the Orissa Act a Grama Sasan can be constituted by notification by the State Government. The Grama Sasan is to be a body corporate having perpetual succession and a common seal with power to acquire and hold property... The appointment of a Sarpanch, therefore, was not by the Government... Under s. 8, the Sarpanch has to act under the authority of the Grama Panchayat... received no remuneration from the Government. The power to remove a Sarpanch by the State Government is stated in s. 16 but the removal can only be for negligence, inefficiency or misbehaviour.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: within such time as may be specified in that behalf by the Central Government. Section 409 empowers the Central Government to prevent change in the nu

arguments.court_reasoning: Factors support no service relation; restricted removal not conclusive

arguments.claim: Three key factors for service of Government lacking: appointment by govt, acts under govt authority, remuneration from govt; removal power not conclusive (analogies to Municipal Acts).

anchor.surface_text: This restricted power of removal was not a conclusive factor on the question whether a Sarpanch was in the service of the Government. It was accordingly urged that three important factors to be taken into consideration in deciding whether a person was in the service of the Government, namely, appointment of the person, such a person to act under the authority of the Government and one who received remuneration from Government were lacking in the case of a Sarpanch... Instances were not lacking in the Municipal Acts of various States where the State Government had vested in it the power of removal of a Chairman of the Municipality, but it could not be said that the members of the Municipality or their Chairman were in the service of the Government.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: within such time as may be specified in that behalf by the Central Government. Section 409 empowers the Central Government to prevent change in the nu

arguments.claim: 'In service of Government' wider than 'serving under'; governmental functions = in service; Sarpanch equated to patwari etc.; 'and' before classes in s.123(7) read as 'or'.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of respondent No. 1 it was urged that the expression in service of Government had a wider concept than the expression serving under the Government. Exercise of governmental functions would amount to being in Governments service. A Sarpanch could be equated with a patwari, Lekhpal, talati, karnam, etc., and it was not necessary to consider whether he was in service of Government because the word and before the words belonging to any of the following classes should be read as or

arguments.court_reasoning: Both elements required ('and'); Sarpanch not revenue officer/village accountant; service requires master-servant

arguments.claim: Provisions of Orissa Act show Grama Panchayat/Sarpanch under govt control/supervision (ss.10,11,14,16,17,22,32,35,36,44,97,98,99,117A), performing governmental duties; control/removal key to service.

anchor.surface_text: He referred to the various provisions of the Orissa Act in support of his submission that a Sarpanch must be regarded as one in service of Government. Under s.10(2) the District Magistrate... Under s.16 the State Government is empowered to remove a Sarpanch... Under s.36 all members of the Grama Panchayat shall be deemed to be public servants... It was urged on behalf of respondent No. 1 that the above provisions of the Orissa Act clearly made the Grama Panchayat come under the control and supervision of the State Government and that the duties and functions of the Grama Panchayat to be performed by its Sarpanch were governmental duties. It was further urged that ... essential elements ... control and supervision over him by the State Government and its power to remove him from his office.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: within such time as may be specified in that behalf by the Central Government. Section 409 empowers the Central Government to prevent change in the nu

arguments.court_reasoning: Control/supervision administrative, not master-servant; analogies to municipalities, co-ops, companies show not service

arguments.claim: Distinction between 'serving under Government' and 'in the service of the Government'; latter imports master-servant relation (personal service + right to control work).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is a distinction between serving under the Government and in the service of the Government, because while one may serve under a Government, one may not necessarily be in the service of the Government under the latter expression one not only serves under the Government but is in the service of the Government and it imports the relationship of master and servant. There are, according to Batt On the Law of Master and Servant, two essentials to this relationship (1) The servant must be under the duty of rendering personal services to the master ... and (2) the master must have the right to control the servants work ... It is this right of control or interference ... which is the dominant characteristic ... marks off the servant from an independent contractor

arguments.claim: No master-servant between State Govt and Grama Panchayat/Sarpanch; govt/DM/SDM powers are supervisory over administrative functions, akin to municipalities, district boards, co-ops, companies.

anchor.surface_text: None of the provisions of the Orissa Act suggest that as between the State Government and the Grama Panchayat and its Sarpanch any such relationship exists. It is true that the State Government, the District Magistrate and the Sub-divisional Magistrate have been given certain powers of control and supervision over the Grama Panchayat but those powers of control and supervision are in relation to the administrative functions of the Grama Panchayat and the Sarpanch. The Grama Panchayat is an autonomous body ... Its administrative functions are akin to the functions generally performed by Municipalities and District Boards. ... Co-operative societies generally are very much under the control and supervision by the State Government ... Even with respect to companies, progressively, legislation has been giving power to the Government to control and supervise them.

arguments.claim: S.123(7) post-amendment narrower than old s.123(8); applies only to persons in service AND belonging to specified classes a-g; cl.f requires revenue officer including village accountants (patwaris etc.), excludes other village officers.

anchor.surface_text: There is a material difference between the phraseology of s. 123(8) before it was amended and s. 123(7) as now contained in the Act. Under the former provision there was a prohibition against obtaining any assistance ... from any person serving under the Government ... After the amendment, however, the provisions of s. 123(7) are narrower in scope. These provisions apply to any person in the service of the Government belonging to the classes specified in cls. (a) to (g) and no one else. For the purpose of this appeal it is cl. (f) which will have to be considered ... Clause (f), in the first instance, speaks of a person in the service of the Government who is a revenue officer and then further extends the class to village accountants. The words such as patwaris, lekhpals, talatis, karnams and the like are merely descriptive ... The exclusion of every other village officer from the provisions of cl. (f) compels the conclusion that ... it must be proved that he is either a revenue officer or a village accountant.

arguments.claim: Sarpanch not revenue officer or village accountant; s.31 tax collection contractual not obligatory; no assigned revenue functions; choukidar handles boundaries (s.54).

anchor.surface_text: The mere fact that under s. 31 of the Orissa Act a Grama Panchayat is enabled to enter into a contract with the State Government to collect its taxes or its dues cannot convert a Sarpanch into a revenue officer. No doubt a Grama Panchayat would have to supervise and maintain village and field boundary marks and village records if required to do so by the State Government under s. 21(r) of the Orissa Act. In the present case there is no proof that the Grama Panchayats in question were required to do any such thing by the Government. It is significant that under s. 54(1)(xiv) of the Orissa Act it is a choukidar ... on whom a statutory duty is cast to keep watch over boundary marks ... The Grama Panchayat, however, has not been assigned positively any functions under the Orissa Act which are discharged by a revenue officer.

arguments.claim: High Court erred: exercising governmental duties does not make Sarpanch in service; no finding he is revenue officer/accountant.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court erred in supposing that because a Sarpanch of a Grama Panchayat under the Orissa Act exercised governmental duties he must be regarded as a person in the service of the Government. The High Court did not give any clear finding that a Sarpanch, even if a person in the service of the Government, was either a revenue officer or a village accountant. In our opinion, the provisions of s. 123(7) do not apply to him. Therefore, it cannot be said that any corrupt practice under s. 123 had been established ... The appeal is accordingly allowed with costs and the election petition of respondent No.

holdings.text: It seems to us unnecessary to decide whether in a case of this kind the provisions of Art. 133 1 c applied because... we grant the appellant special leave to appeal against the decision of the High Court of Orissa and proceed to deal with the appeal on that basis.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us unnecessary to decide whether in a case of this kind the provisions of Art. 133 1  c  applied because, in our opinion, even if they did number apply and the High Court companyld number have issued a certificate, this was just the kind of case where we would have granted special leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution because the appeal raised a point of law of companysiderable public importance. In order to remove all doubts in the matter, we grant the appellant special leave to appeal against the decision of the High Court of Orissa and proceed to deal with the appeal on that basis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Case raises point of law of considerable public importance warranting special leave even if Art.133(1)(c) inapplicable.

holdings.text: There is a material difference between the phraseology of s. 123(8) before it was amended and s. 123(7) as now contained in the Act... These provisions apply to any person in the service of the Government belonging to the classes specified in cls. (a) to (g) and no one else.

anchor.surface_text: There is a material difference between the phraseology of s. 123 8  before it was amended and s. 123 7  as number companytained in the Act. Under the former provision there was a prohibition against obtaining any assistance for the furtherance of the prospect of a candidates election from any person serving under the Government of India or the Government of a State other than the giving of a vote by such person. The Explanation, however, gave authority to the Central Government to declare any person serving under it to be a person to whom these provisions would number apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-amendment s.123(7) narrower than pre-amendment s.123(8), limited to persons in service AND in specified classes.

holdings.text: In our opinion, there is a distinction between serving under the Government and in the service of the Government... it imports the relationship of master and servant.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is a distinction between I serving under the Government and I in the service of the Government, because while one may serve under a Government, one may number necessarily be in the service of the Government under the latter expression one number only serves under the Government but is in the service of the Government and it imports the relationship of master and servant. There are, according to Batt  On the Law of Master and Servant , two essentials to this relationship  1  The servant must be under the duty of rendering personal services to the master or to others in his behalf and  2  the master must have the right to companytrol the servants work either personally or by another servant or agent and,

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'In service of Government' requires master-servant relation: personal service duty and right to control work.

holdings.text: None of the provisions of the Orissa Act suggest that as between the State Government and the Grama Panchayat and its Sarpanch any such [master-servant] relationship exists.

anchor.surface_text: None of the provisions of the Orissa Act suggest that as between the State Government and the Grama Panchayat and its Sarpanch any such relationship exists. It is true that the State Government, the District Magistrate and the Sub-divisional Magistrate have been given certain powers of companytrol and supervision over the Grama Panchayat but those powers of companytrol and supervision are in relation to the administrative functions of the Grama Panchayat and the Sarpanch. The Grama Panchayat is an autonomous body ...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Govt powers over Grama Panchayat/Sarpanch supervisory/administrative, akin to municipalities/boards/co-ops/companies, not master-servant.

holdings.text: We have been unable to find a single provision of the Orissa Act from which we could say that a Sarpanch is a person in the service of the Government.

anchor.surface_text: We have been unable to find a single provision of the Orissa Act from which we companyld say that a Sarpanch is a person in the service of the Government. Reference had been made on behalf of the respondent No. 1 to s. 31 of the Orissa Act which authorizes the Grama Panchayat to enter into a companytract with the State Government to companylect all or any class of taxes or dues payable to the Government at a prescribed percentage as companylection charges.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No appointment/pay by govt, acts under Panchayat, govt powers not creating service relation; s.31 contractual not obligatory.

holdings.text: Clause (f)... speaks of a person in the service of the Government who is a revenue officer and then further extends the class to village accountants... excluding other village officers.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  f , in the first instance, speaks of a person in the service of the Government who is a revenue officer and then further extends the class to village accountants. The words such as patwaris, lekhpals, talatis, karnams and the like are merely descriptive ... The exclusion of every other village officer from the provisions of cl.  f  companypels the companyclusion that ... it must be proved that he is either a revenue officer or a village accountant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.(f) limited to revenue officers/village accountants (descriptive examples); excludes other village officers.

holdings.text: a Sarpanch of the Grama Panchayat under the Orissa Act is neither a revenue officer nor a village accountant.

anchor.surface_text: a Sarpanch of the Grama Panchayat under the Orissa Act is neither a revenue officer number a village accountant. It follows, therefore, that in the present case the two essential elements

holdings.reasoning_summary: No revenue functions assigned; tax collection contractual (s.31); boundary records supervisory if required (s.21(r)), choukidar duty (s.54).

holdings.text: It follows, therefore, that in the present case the two essential elements that a Sarpanch must be a person in the service of the Government and that he belongs to the class mentioned in cl. f of sub-s. 7 of s. 123 have not been established.

anchor.surface_text: It follows, therefore, that in the present case the two essential elements that a Sarpanch must be a person in the service of the Government and that he belongs to the class mentioned in cl.  f  of sub-s.  7  of s. 123 have number been established. Even if one of them had been established and number the other the provisions of s. 123 7  would number apply to such a person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both elements required for s.123(7)(f); neither satisfied.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the High Court erred in supposing that because a Sarpanch of a Grama Panchayat under the Orissa Act exercised governmental duties he must be regarded as a person in the service of the Government... the provisions of s. 123(7) do not apply to him. Therefore, it cannot be said that any corrupt practice under s. 123 had been established

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court erred in supposing that because a. Sarpanch of a Grama Panchayat under the Orissa Act exercised governmental duties he must be regarded as a person in the service of the Government. The High Court did number give any clear finding that a Sarpanch, even if a person in the service of the Government, was either a revenue officer or a village accountant. In our opinion, the provisions of s. 123 7  do number apply to him. Therefore, it cannot. be said that any companyrupt practice under s. 123 had been established ... The appeal is accordingly allowed with companyts and the election petition of respondent No.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred on service and class; no corrupt practice; election not void on this ground.

holdings.text: The appeal is accordingly allowed with costs and the election petition of respondent No.
